            I am a PhD candidate in the Department of Epidemiology at the Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health. My work spans several topics in clinical and social epidemiology, but it is united by a keen interest in careful design and causal inference. Currently, this includes:
            Running two large randomized controlled trials in Uganda and Peru testing social theories about how to reduce male violence and improve equity for women.
            Theorizing about the time-varying effects of nonpharmaceutical interventions during the COVID-19 pandemic.
            Developing methods for time-dependent risk prediction and population-level risk prediction and improving algorithmic fairness using the g-formula.
            In this, I am aided by a fantastic, multi-displinary set of collaborators and mentors who keep me sane and are an endless source of good ideas. When not writing or coding, I enjoy baking and spending time with my wife, Jama, and our cantankerous feline, Ursula üòº.
            
            Education
            PhD Candidate, Epidemiology, Harvard University, 2022 (expected).
            MS Biostatistics, Harvard University, 2022 (expected).
            MPH Epidemiology, Columbia University, 2015.
            BS Mechanical Engineering, Wright State University, 2010.
            
            
            Experience
            Research Analyst. Innovations for Poverty Action, 2015 - 2018.
            Consultant. World Bank, 2016 - 2017.
            Science teacher. Peace Corps (Mozambique), 2010 - 2013.

articles.title: Software
articles.contents:
Below is a list of software that I‚Äôve developed or contributed to:
R
globorisk. An R package for calculating risks of CVD using Globorisk.
gmethods. An R package for estimating causal effects using Robins‚Äô ``g-methods‚Äô‚Äô, i.e.¬†the g-formula, g-estimation, and inverse probability weighting. (In development)
Stata
ipacheck. A Stata package for running high-frequency checks on survey data for field experiments. With Rosemarie Sandino, Ishmail Baako, Caton Brewster, and Isabel O√±ate.
bcstats. A Stata program for analyzing back check (field audit) data and comparing it to the original survey data. With Matthew White.
surveycto_api. A Stata program to automate downloading data from SurveyCTO server using the API.
photobook. A Stata program to create a nicely formatted photobook from a list of image files.

articles.title: Teaching
articles.contents:
Below is a list of courses for which I‚Äôve served as a teaching fellow.
EPI207 - Advanced Epidemiologic Methods
Instructor: James Robins
Terms: Fall 2020, Fall 2021
Required course for epidemiology PhD students. Causal inference for time-varying exposures: g-formula, inverse-probability weighting, marginal structural models, static and dynamic treatment regimes. Responsible for leading 90 min lab section and grading homeworks and tests.
Slides and code for lab on parametric g-formula.
PHS2000 - Quantitative reseach methods
Instructors: Tyler Vanderweele, Michael Hughes, Issa Dahabreh, and Jarvis Chen
Terms: Fall 2019, Spring 2020, Fall 2021
Year-long required methods course for first-year PhD students. Regression models, sampling, longitudinal and multilevel analysis, time-varying confounding, mediation and interaction, econometric methods, and missing data. Responsible for leading 90 min lab section, developing homework assignments and tests, and drafting course materials.
Slides and code for bootcamp review on linear regression.
Handout and code for lab on sensitivity analysis.
Handout and code for lab on causal interaction and effect modification.
Handout and code for lab on mediation.
Handout and code for lab on the bootstrap.
* Distinction in Teaching Award
